name: FileStat
comment: A FileStat object represents the result of calling the POSIX stat() function on a file system object. It is an immutable object, representing the snapshotted values returned by the stat() call.

changed.name: changed
changed.comment: The time of the last change to the data or metadata of the file system object. On Windows platforms, this is instead the file creation time.

modified.name: modified
modified.comment: The time of the last change to the data of the file system object.

accessed.name: accessed
accessed.comment: The time of the last access to the data of the file system object. On Windows platforms, this may have 1 day granularity, and be out of date by an hour.

type.name: type
type.comment: The type of the object (file, directory, or link). If the call to stat() fails, the type of the returned object is NOT_FOUND.

mode.name: mode
mode.comment: The mode of the file system object. Permissions are encoded in the lower 16 bits of this number, and can be decoded using the dart-io.FileStat.modeString getter.

size.name: size
size.comment: The size of the file system object.

statSync.name: statSync
statSync.comment: Calls the operating system's stat() function on dart-io.FileStat.statSync.path. Returns a dart-io.FileStat object containing the data returned by stat(). If the call fails, returns a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

stat.name: stat
stat.comment: Asynchronously calls the operating system's stat() function on dart-io.FileStat.stat.path. Returns a Future which completes with a dart-io.FileStat object containing the data returned by stat(). If the call fails, completes the future with a dart-io.FileStat object with .type set to FileSystemEntityType.NOT_FOUND and the other fields invalid.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

modeString.name: modeString
modeString.comment: Returns the mode value as a human-readable string, in the format "rwxrwxrwx", reflecting the user, group, and world permissions to read, write, and execute the file system object, with "-" replacing the letter for missing permissions. Extra permission bits may be represented by prepending "(suid)", "(guid)", and/or "(sticky)" to the mode string.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.FileStat.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.FileStat.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.FileStat.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.FileStat.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.FileStat.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.FileStat.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.FileStat.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
